channel.title: Webinar with the European Commission and AP Community
channel.description:
![fediverse-european-commission-event-2021-square4|405x358](upload://tcBYtGzxHooA8wdzxmJEVkm9Fq3.svg)
Recently the NGI0 consortium reached out to relay a request from the European Commission to organize a _Webinar_ with the ActivityPub community to discuss the protocols and how they could become a standard for EU institutions to use, with the idea of removing some dependency on centralized networks and the companies promoting them. This would be a maximum of 2 hours, and we certainly could use the opportunity to use the new _live_ feature of #software:peertube to host the webinar. I would like to propose that we start with having a preparation conversation here to summarize the points we could use to demonstrate why the EC should consider ActivityPub, and then take a moment to _eat our own dog food_ and test drive this Peertube Live feature (which so far did not work for me). ### Update 13 April: For newcomers to this very long thread some links: - Planning preparation meetups: https://socialhub.activitypub.rocks/t/preparation-meetups-for-ec-events-editable-wiki/1587 - These are the presentations we are currently improving: - Introductory presentation: https://pad.public.cat/ngi0-ec-activitypub-liaison-presentation-2021-04-19-intro# - ActivityPub for Administrations: https://pad.public.cat/ngi0-ec-activitypub-liaison-presentation-2021-04-19?both# - This is where we keep general notes: https://pad.public.cat/ngi0-ec-activitypub-liaison?both# - This is the NGI Zero announcement you can share: https://www.ngi.eu/event/ngi-breaks-down-walls-decentralize-social-networking-with-activitypub/ - This is our own announcement page you can share: https://socialhub.activitypub.rocks/pub/ec-ngi0-liaison-webinars-and-workshop-april-2021 --- (Besides on this thread, there's other comments on: https://socialhub.activitypub.rocks/t/meeting-notes-for-prep-call-ec-webinar-19-april/1567)

item.dc:creator: cwebber
item.description:
Hey there…

I thought the stuff added to the hedgedoc text was good. FYI I’ll be actually presenting starting from a different document; I only have so much time left to prepare, and it’s easiest to build the best presentation I can using the software I usually use (Racket’s Slideshow, that way I can reuse useful components from previous talks quickly).

I’m borrowing most of the structure from the HedgeDoc writeup, but I have a new title, building on a theme I think is appropriate for this talk: “Decentralized Networked Communities as Essential Infrastructure”

Here is the high-level outline, which you can see as fairly similar to the Hedgedoc one:

  • Introduction
  • Social Centralization, Social Harm
  • Federation, Past and Present
  • The Future of Decentralization
  • Essential Infrastructure

The end then is where I think the EU/EC can collaborate with the fediverse on a direction that is healthy for countries and their citizens/residents, bringing it home in a way that is positive and actionable, I hope.

item.title: Webinar with the European Commission and AP Community
item.dc:creator: mathewlowry
item.description:
2 quick clarifications:

CristinaDeLisle:

His main criticism was that current big platform spend a lot of resources to invest in outreching citizens and they are doing a good job from the perspective of the audience. It does not matter much that it’s a direct approach or a mediated one… I’ve seen this idea with direct outreach as an important point mentioned in some other places

The main problem I had with Unmediated Citizen Engagement is this:
a) the EC spends a lot of time using social media platforms to reach citizens. I am not a fan of this approach, but at the time they saw it as a lot easier than the alternative - making their own website interactive and building a community there (more here: From #EP2009 to #EP2019: a lost decade?)
b) this slide (seems to) argues that the EC can reach citizens now via the Fediverse . This is not true, yet. We could use their help in making it happen, but from the perspective of the EC’s social media teams, spending resources on the Fediverse would appear to be a waste of time, as almost noone is there.

So all that’s really needed is to:

  • emphasise the benefits of having unmediated access - ie, the benefits to them of a successful Fediverse
  • emphasise that they can help make the Fediverse successful by posting there anyway.
CristinaDeLisle:

At Inter-department communication he said it does not reflect how the EU works and people will laugh at us.

As I said in a meeting, the EC has been enduring an internal debate on what internal comms tools to use for many years. They won’t want to open that up again. There’s no chance they’ll use the Fediverse for internal comms. Trying to sell that simply looks naive, sorry.
